entry.title: Combined summary - 64 bit arithmetic soft fork
entry.summary:
The proposal suggests changes to the Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) for arithmetic opcodes, advocating for a mechanism where an overflow would push both the result and overflow amount onto the stack. This change would simplify handling larger numbers, making overflow detection easier and reducing the need for additional operations.
An analysis points to a potential increase in blockchain storage requirements with a transition to 8-byte encodings for ScriptNums, potentially expanding the blockchain by about 1GB or 0.17% since its inception. A GitHub repository ([this GitHub repository](https://github.com/Christewart/bitcoin-s-core/tree/2024-01-19-count-scriptnums)) provides access to a JSON file and source code to validate these projections based on testnet3 environment assessments.
Rusty Russell's article proposes simplifying arithmetic opcodes and introduces a generic opcode for adjusting byte numbers. The debate centers around adding new opcodes for 64-bit number handling versus upgrading existing ones. Future advancements may eliminate the need for `SCRIPT_VERIFY_MINIMAL_DATA`, but there is skepticism about removing the flag due to the necessity of backward compatibility.
Further discussions involve memory and disk space concerns linked to certain opcodes, with BIP62 addressing transaction malleability issues. Thereâ€™s also a suggestion to standardize number encodings into a single format, considering impacts on wallet software and the NFT space due to prevalent use of `OP_PUSHDATAx`.
The reintroduction of 256-bit arithmetic post-Taproot is considered, weighing the benefits of enabling complex cryptographic operations against maintaining blockchain efficiency. Technical considerations include space optimization through minimal encodings like `CScriptNum` and the challenges it poses for developers.
Endianness confusion around `CScriptNum` is addressed, with evidence pointing towards little endian encoding. Discussions compare fixed-length versus variable-length encoding methods and two's complement system versus a sign bit for negative numbers, which significantly affect script processing efficiency.
The importance of safety checks during integer overflows is discussed, particularly within the Elements system. Flexibility in consensus rules, such as tapscript leaf versions, and potential changes to flags like `SCRIPT_VERIFY_MINIMALIF` are contemplated for network robustness.
The conversation reviews the significance of consistent numeric values during script execution. New opcodes that handle unsigned numbers and increased precision are proposed, including reactivating operations such as multiplication and left shift. A blog post by Rusty provides further insights ([Rusty's Blog](https://rusty.ozlabs.org/2023/12/30/arithmetic-opcodes.html)).
Implementation and extension of `CScriptNum` for 64-bit arithmetic in scripting are highlighted, with a commitment link demonstrating how to extend support across numeric opcodes ([GitHub Commit](https://github.com/halseth/bitcoin/pull/1/commits/13c1848edf66410517b3cb6d47d80874438abb1f)). The ongoing discussion also includes the proposed introduction of a new opcode `OP_ENABLE64BIT` to expand computational ranges for arithmetic operations, with strict placement at the beginning of scripts to avoid unintended outcomes.
A potential soft fork solution for the `OP_ENABLE64BIT` opcode is suggested for maintaining validity of scripts containing it without affecting current consensus rules. The preference for little endian encoding over big endian is debated, considering the impact on witness sizes and opcode space.
The integration of covenant opcodes for more dynamic conditions in smart contracts represents a significant advancement in cryptocurrency programming. Incorporating 64-bit arithmetic into various coding tasks reflects the industry's drive for optimization.
The relevance of 64-bit arithmetic across different protocols is emphasized, and early feedback on a drafted BIP and its implementation is sought through available links ([BIP proposal link](https://github.com/Christewart/bips/pull/1) and [implementation link](https://github.com/Christewart/bitcoin/pull/2)), despite such discussions typically not occurring in the referenced forum.
